description.text: This is a 3d model of an Altus Metrum EasyMini rocket altimeter. I wanted to know if an EasyMini would fit in a 29mm min-diameter high power rocket I'm making before I spent the money to buy one. So, I used the measurements and photos from their website to make a 3d model. It looked like it would work, so I bought one and then updated the model. This version isn't perfect, but it's really close to the size of the EasyMini (version 1.0).

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

There are 3 model files included. For most printers, you'll want to print the "top" and "bottom" files then glue them together. The full model file is also included in case you'd like to use that to model other parts (i.e. your rocket's avionics sled). Once you print the top & bottom, glue them together using a plastic glue. For orientation of the two halves, refer to Altus Metrum's website.

For your reference, the circuit board itself is about 1.6mm thick. The EasyMini's overall height is about 12.5mm, width is 21mm (plus a very small amount for the USB connector) and the length is about 38.7mm.

remixed_from.author: iamjonlawrence
remixed_from.title: Timing Belt X MXL, Printrbot Simple V2

title: Timing Belt X GT2, Printrbot Simple V2

description.text:
This will work for both V2 designs (with & w/o string tension) In response to multiple requests I have developed this GT2 timing belt conversion for the X axis of the Printrbot Simple. This thing is similar to my original http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:191706 Differences are:
  • Use GT2 belt & pulley instead of the MXL
  • Use 608 Bearings instead of R2
  • Raises print bed 6.5mm
    • Benefits:
  • GT2 tooth form
  • Common 608 Bearings
    • Drawbacks:
  • Bearing Caps have very thin wall due to limited space.
  • Decreases available Z height by raising print bed.
    • For anybody having trouble printing these parts I have uploaded a 2014 version to Shapeways if you would like to order them online. http://shpws.me/rbxE This is marked as a work in progress. If you have a success (or failure) please let me know. Feedback is greatly appreciated. REV A:
  • Made plate thinner to allow for some Z calibration error.
  • Raised motor height by 2mm to allow more clearance between belt pulley and lower wood plate.
  • Re-worked belt ends and lower plate orientation to allow for entire 100mm travel.
  • Eliminated need for raising the build plate.
    • REV B:
  • Removed excess material inside bearing slot to allow 100mm travel.
  • Removed material to allow clearance for tie wrap end.
    • REV C:
  • Updated the right hand belt end file "XBeltEndGT2RevC.stl" to give some clearance for the 2014 fan. This moves the tension mount 15mm further out and gives plenty of room for the fan to clear.
    • REV D:
  • Updated the motor mount plate to allow some clearance around the 22mm motor pilot dimension. If the motor plate does not sit flush then when you tighten the motor mounting screws you can warp the plate pulling the bearings out of alignment. "MotorMountXGt2-RevD.stl" will help correct this interference.
    • For discussion of the evolution of this project please refer to http://www.printrbottalk.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=106&t=5697 Special thanks goes out to ahaer for all the R&D work!

Just a "head's up"  
In order to replace the X axis motor plate, ALL sides of the machine will have to be removed. This includes sliding the Z rods out of the base plate.  You don't have to remove them from the top plate, but they will need to come out of the bottom plate.  
The dis-assembly is more scary than difficult. Simply be mentally prepared for a complete dis-assembly of all sides and it won't be too bad.  
Your efforts WILL be rewarded, and you will not want to return to the string drive.  
One tip on threading the belt:  Using a 4 inch length of sticky tape cut to the same width as the belt, stick one side to the top of the pulley, and rotate it around until it comes up on the other side. Then stick the smooth side of the belt to the tape and carry on turning it through, pulling gently on the end of the tape.   
Enjoy!

comments.text: Today I did the install of the X and Y GT belt upgrade. First, the parts are amazing, very nicely designed. I do like the organic and rounded nature of the design. For me the install was a PITA. This is nothing against the design. It was just a royal pain and took me many more hours than I anticipated. I had to tweek so much in order to get everything to fit right. It's amazing it worked! I love the replacement X motor plate. But I had to do things like grind the over-all length of a GT bolt down and add spacers to some parts to get everything to work and provide clearance between the pulleys and bearings and etc. I think I spent about 4 hours with it. But its printing fine now. A worthy upgrade but best assume its going to be a pain and that you will need to tweek things to make it all fit right.

comments.text: Your mod is great John. The Y-axis took hardly any effort to implement. The x-axis however, on my printrbot simple XL ordered fall 2013 gives me the same problems decribed here. The top of the bolt holding the x-stopper scrapes along the base of the bed. It took a bit of Dremeling of the bed to overcome that problem.  Second, the zip ties holding the rods and bed hit the sides of the printer, thus preventing full movement in the x direction. It seems that either the holes in the plate holding the bearing are a bit wider than in other  versions, lowering the axis or that the slots in the bed. This however must have existed before and have passed unnoticed. Anyhow, my solution will be to lasercut a piece to highten the axes or tho dremel out the sides of the printer.
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text:
I have the head of the m3 screw closest to the printer on the x endstop switch rubbing on my lower bed frame as well, when the lower bed frame is inserted bacckwards. I tested it on my stock bed and the xl/tower bed. Both of them rub on that screw and prevent it from strapping down the zipgties completely/or moving the bed if you do. I was able to remove that screw with the allen key hole and replaced it with a flatghead philips m3 machine screw. That little bit of a difference gives it the room it needs to move freely. It still looks like it is touching, but is not restricting any movement now.
One other note for anyone using the tower/volume upgrade, there is an extra 6mm wooden plate added to the left side of the stock printrbot simple to make the tower. The left belt arm will not clear this wall and will not allow the bed to hit the x-endstop switch. The fix is as sime as filing about 1/8th of an inch off the arm right at the 45 degree bend. Just takes a couple minutes to give clearance.
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text: What I did was unscrew the one screw that was barely rubbing, and twist the switch to move the screw hole forward a tiny bit. I just need to drill a new hole for the screw I removed from the limit switch, and also drill a hole for the screw that engages the limit switch when the limit is reached, and I should be ready to start printing again.

title: Remix Mini Monster Truck w/ Rotating Wheels
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of the Mini Monster Truck. I didn't like that it didn't have rotating wheels, so I used Emmett's Gear Bearing to make wheels that work. I have included the step files and the Scad file for the bearing.

Used Maker Geeks PLA & Maker Flex PLA for the tires. Prints like a dream.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

No supports where needed for my printer but they may be needed for other printers.

On the bearing all that had to be done is resizing it and adding the following lines to the top of the file:
translate([-2,-2,17])cube(4,center);
translate([0,0,15])cylinder(2,r=3.5,center);

With that being done the bearings acted as pegs and then I super glued them together. I decided to make the car and truck bodies separate so that people could create their own things to put on them.

I used and app called Shapr3D on my iPad Pro using the Apple Pencil. This made it easy for designing.

comments.text: The frame had issues for me in Slic3r and were kind of hard to figure out how to get fixed. I ended up using netfab to do it, and it was the only method I tried that worked.

remixed_from.title: Middle Tree Perk Build-A-Bong - Proof Of Concept

description.text:
This is a final Product of the "Middle Tree Perk Build-A-Bong - Proof Of Concept"

This is the first of many in a line of 3D printed Build-a-Bongs.

Essentially I just had to get the sizing down so that there was little to 0 air loss (if you want 0 i suggest a 0.1 height layer and slowing the print speed to 40 mm/s essentially printing in high quality or equivalent of your printer.)

Tested proven and works. (I printed mine at a height of 120 mm)

The tree perk was moved to the bottom of the tube for better adhesion to the build plate (especially for those without heated build plates) and because you cant see through the plastic, there's no need for the perk to be in an aesthetically pleasing place.

Printer:

MOD-t

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

do 100% infill for absolute 0 air loss! (haven't tried 0.2 m with 100% infill...yet, I will update when i get around to it!)
It sits snugly inside, and even works with K-clips!

"Arca-Swiss Style" Quick-Release plate.
I used this to replace a normal metal plate on my 3D printed panoramic camera. I just super-glued this onto my existing printed camera. For the rest of my 3D printed cameras I integrated this plate into the actual design so that it printed out with the camera itself.

I have included the OpenScad file in case you want to modify for your needs or incorporate it into one of your designs.

Printer:

MakerFarm Prusa 8

No

No

200 micron

10%

description.text:
With plenty of love shown for the North American SNES for raspberry pi cases and the more aesthetically appealing (imo) PAL version being left behind, I decided to model one to suit a Pi-zero with working buttons and front facing USB ports.

It's a very easy print but requires some soldering for the USB ports and network card to work, I have written a draft guide for this but made a mistake with the GPIO wiring for the buttons. I aim to update this before Christmas 2016. I have uploaded all the images anyway in the hopes that you can see the general idea and make the corrections as you go. Otherwise simply leaving the buttons disconnected will work for the time being.

My XYZ orientation screws up the STL export so you will need to re-orientate the parts before slicing.

Supports are required for the top & bottom shell and I recommend removing any supports under the rear vent if your slicer supports it.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

BOM can be viewed using the link below.

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1F_ArzNiFwMW9JimI16obwYbLgVDuH2v6bz6ATh1kTYQ/pubhtml?gid=0&single=true

All the parts are printed and cleaned up. Most of the major components gathered. The HDMI adapter needs to have the plastic casing removed, pretty easy with a hobby knife. USB wires prepped for the front facing ports, about 100mm long is plenty. Wire up and solder the female usb ports, use the orientation of the ports on the USB hub as wiring reference. Repeat for the other USB port. The USB port on the far end needs to be removed to allow for clearance needed for the power button switch terminals, the other ports aren’t needed either since I am wiring directly to the PCB but they’re not in the way so they can stay. First front facing port soldered on, try to avoid this much exposed wires if possible. Place the new USB port flat on the table the same way up as the existing ports and make sure the wires match the USB pins on the PCB. Second one soldiered on. Second one soldiered on. Wiring up the power switch, I used a small LED and battery to test which terminals to use. About 100mm of wire is enough. Heat sink on both wires and then connected to the ground wire of the power USB port, I added some glue to the wires to keep them from shorting since my soldering caused the insulation to burn a bit. Soldier about 40-50mm of wire onto the momentary switch and then add heatsink. I later found that these terminals were a bit too long and made for a very tight fit when putting the case together, It would be worth trimming these down to 2-3mm at most. Then add heatshrink Here’s my wiring diagram, I used the following source to work this out. If my wiring diagram doesn’t make sense it should seem pretty basic after reading the following. https://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/projects/raspberrypi/tutorials/robot/buttons_and_switches/ 1KΩ resistor trimmed short and soldiered in with a second wire soldiered on the switch side for the 10KΩ resistor. Red heat shrink over the 1KΩ resistor and then soldier in the 10KΩ resistor. I used black heat shrink on the 10KΩ and made a note of it so I don’t get them mixed up. The black wire is soldiered onto the switch for ground, the red wire is bundled up neatly with clear heat shrink. Repeat for the other switch. Just lebeling the wires so I remember which resisitor is which. The LED needs a 270Ω resistor wired to the 5v wire and then covered in heat shrink. I think It would be better to use a 3.3V LED to put less load on the PiZero but this is what I had on hand so it’ll do. LED all done. The power switch can be fed through the top of the switch mount and secured in place with glue after connecting it to the ground wire on the power supply USB cable. Just a dab of epoxy to hold it in place. The excess PCB on these USB/LAN hubs needs to be snipped off for it to fit in the enclosure properly. Don't worry, there's no magic stored here. About 2mm or so trimmed off is enough. The USB/LAN hub can be snapped in place, a couple drops of glue underneath wouldn’t hurt although it should already be a pretty tight fit. Tucks the wires in and seat the USB ports in their slots. The flared ends of the USB ports should sit in the retainer slots, this will stop them pulling out or pushing in when using them. The nut and washer can be removed from the LED, these won’t be needed. Everything should fit nice and snug in the slots before adding the clamp. Clamp added and tightened. There should be no pressure in the middle of the USB ports, only on the corners. Most of the pressure will be on the LED as this will be a pretty tight fit, take a little material out of the clamp bracket around the LED if it’s too tight. Trim the LED wires to length, about 75mm will do. I used this image as reference for the GPIO pin locations along with my wiring diagram above. I am using the newer version of the PiZero but the GPIO pins are still the same. LED wires are soldered to the PiZero on the 5v and the GPIO pin, I have routed them up through the bottom to keep the top from getting cluttered Make sure these wires are snug against the PCB with as little exposed wire as possible. The first button soldered in. Second button soldered in. I left a bit too much wire on this one which made it hard to fit everything in. The buttons can then be screwed into the button mount. Buttons in and ready for the button caps. Button caps added, I added a drop of glue to the top of the buttons to keep them from rattling around. The faux cartridge slot can be glued in place from the inside. Test fit of the buttons, You can see my case is a bit rough on the inside from the printed supports. Happy with the fit-up, I glued it in place. Added the HDMI adapter and placed the power cable in it’s slot, It was a bit too tight so I used a craft knife to make a tiny bit more room before gluing it in place. The SD card can be prepared with RetroPie now, everything needed for this can be found here. https://github.com/retropie/retropie-setup/wiki/First-Installation Installed SD card and case assembled Assembly all done, time to program the buttons and LED. Guide for this will be uploaded soon.

description.text:
I can almost never find my tools when I need them. In looking for a better place to keep things, I realized there's a lot of space on the upper crossbar of my printer frame that's totally unused, even when the print bed is at maximum height. So, I printed up some compact holders to slot into the 2020 extrusion frame and neatly organize my tools out of my way.

The holders are designed to fit snugly into the 2020 channel of my FolgerTech printer, though I'm guessing they'll work with any standard 2020 aluminum.

Holder design #1 was designed for my pallet knife, which I use to remove prints from the bed. Design #2 works great for a set of tweezers (which I always seem to need when printing but can never find), and #3 was intended for a file.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Folgertech 2020 Prusia i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

70%

Notes:

The two "fork" style holders (#1 and #3) are intended to be printed with the points of the fork and the base of the T-nut facing down on the build plate. Design #2 prints on its side, with the short edge of the box resting on the build plate. See below for a picture of the preferred printing orientation.

Because the parts are so small and the tolerance for a good, snug fit in the T-channel is so tight, printing in different orientations than described above may result in a less-than-ideal fit. If the fit doesn't work out, scaling the part by a few percent in the direction that isn't fitting may help get a better fit.

A brim may be necessary, especially for the two "fork" style holders (#1 and #3).

Cura was used for support generation at 25% support fill.

description.text:
The egg shape of this toy makes it easier to print, compared to the typical ball shape. I've also placed a rib inside each wall section to help stabilize them during printing, with the bonus of more vigorous bouncing of the pea during use.

UPDATE: I have corrected orientation of the .stl file so it should now load with the egg properly standing on end for printing.

UPDATE: Added an "empty" version, without the enclosed pea. During printing, you can drop in whatever noise making object you like, such as a jingle bell.

Printer:

Geeetech Delta G2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Infill affects only the density of the pea. Higher density generally produces a louder rattle effect. Just break the pea loose after printing.

When printing these in ABS, I have found it helpful to run a print cooling fan gently (30%) during the last half of the print.

remixed_from.author: cathalgarvey
remixed_from.title: DremelFuge - A One-Piece Centrifuge for Rotary Tools

description.text:
RemixChallenge

This is my submission for the remix challenge and it is remix of the dremelfuge by cathalgarvey and this is a hand crank version of what he did.
This prints in roughly 5 hours total and uses a 1:6 gear ratio to take your hand motion and turn it into a super fast centrifuge that could be used for various things without having to own a high power Dremel or other such devices.

(Note: there are some included caps if you choose to use them they are not necessary but make it easier to spin the gears at high speeds)

Printer Brand:

Tinkertine Studio

Printer:

Ditto +

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

300 microns is what i used

Infill:

5 percent is plenty

Notes:

The Files are designed with fast printing in mind so don't worry to much and each separate part(not the caps) should take about an hour to print.

light sanding on the gear shafts is nice and if you chose to print the caps they may need some light sanding to fit depending on your printer. Also make sure you clean any strings of plastic in the gears so it can spin freely.

I used 123D Design and took the dremelfuge model and cut a square hole in it and proceeded to build the mechanism around that by making the gears first and then the base to hold all of the components together. I then took the models and did light clean up in mesh mixer.

comments.text: What a great idea. I can use this for a lot of things.

author: mconger

description.text:
Hinge for light applications.

Dimensions
Width: 25 mm
Length: 51 mm (2 x 25,5)

Depending on the printer setting, small rework is necessary.

The guide hole for the axle should be 2.6 mm in diameter.

Want to upgrade your print-speed? This is an extruder that allows you to mount a beefy, high-torque, NEMA23 stepper motor. You can directly attach it to the Bowden cable. With the Bowden extruder (see my other designs under the Thingiverse tag: bowden), the plastic throughput is your print speed bottleneck. Or should I say, was your bottleneck: With a NEMA23 motor I've been able to extrude more than 15 mm^3 of molten ABS per second. That's about a (fully solid) mendel in 22 hours! So now XY-movements are the bottleneck again. For this, I think I need to further reduce the weight of the carriage (lighter rods, etc.). Usage:
You can simply press the Bowden cable with an M6 nut into the T-slot (to attach the extruder drive mechanism to the extruder head via a Bowden cable).
Note: An M5 nut will also work (for smaller PTFE bowden cables), it will be able to slide slightly, but its movement is constrained by the filament.

• Make your stepper motor shaft rough (e.g. with a dremel cutting disk).
  • Put an M4x16 bolt into the 624 bearing. Put a washer between it and insert it into the printed part as seen in the picture. Put another washer on the other side and fasten it with an M4 nut.
  • Bolt the extruder onto the printed part, with four M5 cap screws, use washers.
  • When using ABS you can tighten it so that the washers will sink into the plastic creating a very tight friction fit. It is soft enough that it won\'t crack. With PLA you should be more careful.
    You can stack several of them with the mounting slots on the sides. This is useful for multi-material RepRaps. The design is future proof :)

description.text: Guild Wars 2 Elite specialization Icon: Dragonhunter

This arm was designed for Kwawu John Mensah through e-NABLE Ghana. This is a remix of Christian Silva’s Flexi Arm 2. This is Christian’s wrist and arm design, with Steve Wood’s Flexi Hand fingers. I have gone back to the fingers of FlexyHand 2. I think they are easier for most people to print and still have a very natural look. The fully enclosed fingers from Steve Wood's Flexy-Hand - Filaflex Remix will also work.

I have made many adjustments to make it easier to build and print. The biggest changes I have made are to include the whipple tree inside the palm, and to include and adjustable cam in the elbow. The cam is reposition-able into four positions determined by four notches. To change the rate of closure of the fingers the user just slides the cam out a little to release it from the notch and rotates it to the next position. I have redesigned this arm to have two string bowden channels one to each side of the elbow. So the thumb is one one side of the elbow and the fingers are on the other side. By adjusting the closure rate of the thumb and fingers separately, the wearer can achieve various grip types.

This is modeled as an adult size. So the proportions are more for an adult then the original FlexiArm2.

This version does not have the forearm cover that the Flexy Arm 2 has. Kwawu did not want a cover. If others would like a version with the cover, please leave me comments I will add a variation with the cover.

I will add a variation with the cover in a few weeks. (Sorry, Thingiverse is not letting me post comments on my own thingi)

description.text:
This is a interchangeable thumb slug for bowling ball that is optimized for 3D-printing. It will fit on the Switchgrip-mechanism.

I have used PETG-material to make this and it works great. In case of using some other material, it may require some tweaking for the clearance at the bottom mechanism. There is no thumb hole included because it will be different from person to person. Also the height of the slug should be adjusted.

Print the thing from bottom to top. Then you will make the top surface to accommodate the ball's surface.

I made the following modifications to larry009's excellent Classic Batmobile model:

  • Smoother body and window surfaces, improved bat images
  • Rotating wheels with axles and optional long axles/spacers
  • Cutouts for bat logos and rocket tubes, hollow rocket tubes
  • Batmobile #1 1955 Lincoln Futura "cutaway" steering wheel
  • Detailed atomic turbine exhaust port and roll-bar pod lights
  • STL file repairs; Reoriented & plated for easier 3D printing

Known issue: no bat-chutes!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

doesn't matter

Notes:

IMPORTANT: Print batmobile-body(use raft).stl with raft. I used 0% infill, 3 shells;
Print batmobile-no_raft.stl without raft, 2 shells, 10% infill. Neither part requires support.
Print the windows in transparent (I used Taulman T-Glase).
I used the longer set of axles with spacers for all wheels.
If possible, use a heated bed when printing the body halves to minimize warping.
See larry009's instructions for more information on painting.

Printing, Painting and Detailing

Here's how I printed and painted my model:
1) I printed the body and wheels in black PLA. I sliced the model with a 0.10mm layer height, which was a mistake. The model took almost 40 hours to print! I should have used 0.20mm layers. Definitely use raft for the body halves. I didn't and the model was knocked over at hour 36. (Heartbreak!) So there's an extra seam on my model where I printed the last bit and glued it on.
Wheels: I brushed silver acrylic onto the rims area and other silver parts. For a better chrome effect, you should use a silver spray paint and then repaint the tires black (or mask them from the spray).
Body: I used Polyfilla to fill the seams between the front and back body halves (and my patched bits) and then repainted the body black. (Alternately, use one or more coats of primer first.)
2) Sand, repeat, sand, repeat until smooth.
3) Print or paint the bat logos in red. I printed the crests in red PLA and glued them in place.
4) Attach the wheels. I used the long axles with the spacers.
5) Glue the various parts onto the body: rocket tubes, seats, dashboards, steering wheel, roll bar, etc.
6) Paint the fine details, such as the orange running lights, red and silver flasher, and red pod lights on the roll bar, with a small brush. If you're really going for it, print tiny descriptive tags for every Bat-gizmo in the dashboard area. My model is missing the all-important Emergency Bat Turn lever, Batphone, Bat-fire extinguisher, and Bat-Ray Projector.
7) Use a red Paint Pen to paint the red pinstripes. It works amazingly well, and it's very easy to control the line thickness. I tried to use a brush (as recommended by larry009 on the original model's source page) and believe me, the paint pen is definitely the way to go. I applied three coats.
8) If possible, apply a coat of XTC-3D or glossy Varathane to both sides of the windows before attaching them. If you want your Batmobile to be glossy (as it was during the TV series years, until George Barris inexplicably decided to resurface the iconic vehicle with a flocked finish he called "Bat Fuzz" in the early seventies), apply XTC-3D or Varathane to everything. My sample photos show a model finished in "Bat Fuzz" black. :-)
9) Attach the windows.

title: Amazon Echo Dot 2nd gen M&S; Intercom Mount

description.text:
M&S Nortek NW65RS / N65RS mount for Amazon Echo Dot 2nd gen. Have one of those intercoms in your house that you never use ? Make it smart with this mount and a low cost Echo Dot. Replace the build in speaker with the Echo Dot using this mount. Inspired and built off of the cool looking Echo Dot Sound Enhancer ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1816654 ).

To make it extra clean, disconnect the 4-wire from the master and the remote unit and use a 24VDC Meanwell power supply with a DROK DC-DC Buck Voltage Converter 4.5-40V 12V to 5V/2A (Amazon) to re-use use the low voltage wiring to power the system. I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1077459 and just mounted it to the back of the enclosure.

Edit 1/22/2017
For whatever reason, my Echo Dots need a hard reboot every so often. I got tired of opening the panel and pulling the plug. After tracing some of the leads with a multi-meter, I found that if you pull one of the wires (white in my case) from the in-wall cabling and solder it to one of the middle lead behind the "Talk" switch as shown in the picture, and just connect the white speaker cable that is already soldered to the board, you can use the "Talk" button to "reboot" the Echo Dot.

Monoprice Flashforge Creator Pro Clone

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

comments.text: The downside to this is you kill any chance the multiple built-in microphones have at balancing how they listen for the commands.  I suppose it's clever to re-use an intercom panel and all, but at the price of losing wake detection and echo-canceling?  Not sure it's a trade off work making.
comments.author: wkearney99

comments.text: Wake detection using any of the wake-words works fine.  I agree we probably  lose some directional discrimination since the microphones are facing towards the panel vs up , however it has not been noticeable with my Echo dots in overall performance since we are generally within 15ft of any of the Echo units.

comments.text: what is that device that turns power into USB port with the screw terminals?
comments.author: nt86

comments.text:
If you are asking about the Voltage Converter (DC - DC 5V 2Amp) it is this : http://a.co/8ZLBjHO . It is a Drok voltage converter. It converts the 120VAC --> 24V (1.5A) Meanwell power supply I put behind the central console.
The optional portion I recently posted was using the 'Talk' button as a reset switch by soldering the - (or +) wire to the solder point on the built in board, and re-using the speaker wire (without desoldering) as shown back to the drok. Essentially, the Talk button will cut the power to the Drok power supply while being held down.

title: Wanhao Duplicator I3 Plus Y Plate (multi fit)

description.text:
Y-Plate replacements for the Wanhao Duplicator I3 Plus. Measure the center-to-center distance of your Y-Shafts and ensure you use the correct file for your printer. The file should work for 3 and 4 bearing models.

If you measure the distance between the two Y-shafts, you should get 142mm for the 150mm file and 132mm for the 140mm file.

The .dxf files can be laser or water-jet cut out of 3mm or 4mm aluminium.

If you find this useful, please feel free to leave a tip.
If you want any changes, feel free to let me know.

description.text:
This is a remix of the Hammer by Walter.

It use some 5mm metal balls to insert into the head.
Using this balls offers 2 advantages :
-It add weight to the head
-and the "flying" balls absorb the impact
Those 2 points add more inertia to the hammer making it more efficient.

I also add parts which i called "shoes" for 2 reasons:
-It is easy to change the day it will be damaged, and it use less filament
-you can use different filament for different uses.

I personnaly printed one shoe in PLA to use it as a hammer, and one in PETG to use it as a part remover. It could be interesting to test other filament like flexible and PC.

The Head and the Handle stl have a tolerance of 0.2mm.
I exported the shoe with different tolerance to be able to fit with any printer tolerance and/or different filament. Let me know if you need other sizes of gap for the shoe.

Notes:

The head and the handle doesn't need a high infill. 30% is good enough.

The shoe will need a higher infill, I'ld recommend at least 70% for durability.

-Plug the handle into the head
-Fill the head with balls through the head's hole. It doesn't need to be entirely filled, actually it is better to let free space to allow balls to absorb the impact.
-Add one or two shoes.

I was using the original one from Walter, printed in PLA, and I really like it. I was using it for many things. But after several mounthes it starts to crack (not really a surprise as it was in PLA). So I was thinking to reprint the head, then I got the idea of design martyr parts.
Doing this I heard about hammers with balls inside....I went for it too.

I wanted to be as close to the Walter's design. The head of my first prototype was closely looking the same. But I couldn't print it without having to deal with messy hoverhangs or supports, and it was creating issues to fit the shoes. That's why I came to a low-poly looking design.

Designed with Openscad.

description.text:
I have made various pulse motors on my learning journey - the last generator I made was great and a fair amount of output but fell short in many areas.
I am learning by doing. so the aim here was to make something that was sturdy and able to be changed with different coils / rotor configurations without anything breaking / falling apart.

Advantages of my new design
Coil Sections are independent and removable
I am now making the most of the magnetic field - two sets of coils per rotor
stackable - we can stack as many units as you want on one drive shaft.
geometry of the rotor and coils - 6 coils and 6 Magents = All coils are "firing" the same time. the last generator had 6 coils with 4 magnets on the rotor and that = 2 coils firing at one time.

RepRap

3d Printed Parts
5mm Threaded Rod
607b Bearings

description.text:
The FA3D Hand: The Functional and Anthropomorphic 3D-printed hand prosthesis.

This prosthesis was designed by Jelle ten Kate as part of his MSc thesis at Delft University of Technology. It was originally printed in NinjaFlex using an FDM printer and assembled using standard nuts and bolts. For a detailed description of the hand, along with its assembly procedure and testing results, refer to the thesis report which can be found at: http://repository.tudelft.nl/islandora/object/uuid:7923ea86-8d83-4acc-95e2-530b18920ee2?collection=education

Full access to the SolidWorks files can be found through the website of the Hand Fund: http://www.handenstichting.nl/en/example-projects/#FA3DHand_en

print_settings.Notes:: You will be able to cut approximately 100mm from the bowden tube.

description.text:
Was very unhappy with the stock extruder setup (too much weight overhanging one corner) and sick of tower wobble ruining the finish of my prints.

Used the factory sketches to design new brackets which locate the extruder underneath the top plate, but above the effector plate. This also eliminates about 100mm from the bowden tube, reducing friction and the chance of the extruder skipping. It also has COMPLETELY eliminated any tower wobble I've had running prints up to 30mm/s, and movement speeds of 150mm/s.

I created a filament guide/cleaner that fits into the top plate, you will need to use an external filament spool.

Both .dxf and .stl files are included for the 6 main brackets - I would HIGHLY recommend you have these made from laser cut 6mm ply (use hobby ply, or laser ply - not marine ply) however you could print if you have no other options.

You will need:

top bracket x4
extruder bracket x1
extruder bracket x1
filament guide/cleaner x1 (printed - flip upside down)
middle bracket x1 (printed - lay flat)
spacer x3 (optional)

Screws needed are M3x30 x3 (or 6 if you use the spacers). Everything else uses the factory setup.

Printer:

Deltaprintr

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

20

Notes:

Stuff the filament cleaner with cotton pads or sponge, depending on what you prefer. A light squirt of machine oil makes the whole thing run much smoother.

You will be able to cut approximately 100mm from the bowden tube.

description.text: Once you have printed it, Enjoy it!!

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 Hephestos

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

12

A fairly basic blended wing aircraft with V-tail. Right now it's just the blocked out as a solid form. I'm thinking of altering it into sections in an attempt to make a flyable model sometime in the future.

--- Edit 12/16/2016 ---

Updated the base mesh. Tail is now welded into the mesh, such that it should be a closed manifold object. Next step is resizing and hollowing out the model. I'll leave the current base mesh file, and new updates will be in additional files. This should make things a bit more convenient for remixing.

--- Edit 12/20/2016 ---

Some preliminary parts. Some early separated components, at the moment these are just the outer shell. Not sure if this is an adequate thickness for the outer skin, so some feedback one way or the other may be useful. I noticed from images of flyable models, some seem to be fairly thin, but how thin can you go?

Also added another .blend file. It should give an idea of component mock-up in regards to future progress.

--- Edit 12/25/2016 ---

Merry Christmas! :) Anyhow some minor progress. Working on modeling interior support structures for the hollowed out shell pieces. Still slow progress. Boolean does so much, but to get it cleaned up it takes manual work. So that's what's going on now.
https://youtu.be/kw1ZJXhMSLE

--- Edit 1/1/2017 ---

A new year already? How about that. Added the next variant of the nose in the .STL files. It's been modified with a motor mount and some basic ventilation.

--- Edit 1/14/2017 ---

Just doing a test since I found Cura was open source. Still don't have a 3D printer though. Got an inner wing section from the .STL to fit in the box for Utilmaker 3 in Cura and it doesn't seem to show any obvious errors. Some other stuff may be a bit big for many printers, so I may have to adjust the breakdown again. Yeah I'm a noob at this. :)

This is still quite involved. I suspect the better known 3D-printed planes must have a whole team of people working on them. Would be nice to get some collab work on this one. Anyone?

By the way, the gcode file from that test has been uploaded.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Mech City is a 3D printable line of cute mecha, accessories, little people, and play sets! The Mech City Play Set contains hex tiles of different count sizes, roads and overpasses, and a modular building that can be assembled in a number of different ways. The printed hexes are about 70mm (~2.75") across and will quickly fill up a shelf. The hex tiles and city buildings and roads would work well for a miniatures game board, though you'd have to experiment to see how small you can get everything.

This is a quick video showing the parts for this set

LulzBot

Mini

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

For the basic building you'll need to print 4 of side.stl
all of the parts have some texturing on the bed side of the model to make them easier to get off the build plate, keep it in mind if you have issues w/ parts sticking already. I also went through an entire roll of PLA printing out everything shown in the video so you could try lowering the infill or shell thickness if you want to be more conservative with your material usage and print times. Due to my printer's build size, I was unable to print any of the hex tiles larger than the hex-2 so the larger ones are still untested.. :/

RemixChallenge

The Bearded Yell & Athena of Velletri

Inspired by a famous ambiguous optical illusion, "My Wife and My Mother-in-Law", published by British cartoonist William Ely Hill (1887–1962), this work was the ideal theme/starting point for the Remix Challenge.

The picture is a remix, too, mixing the Young and the Old Lady. So, that’s what I decided to do with The Bearded Yell by #bendansie and Athena of Velletri by #CosmoWenman, mixing both for the #RemixChallenge.

Depending on your mood, you can have a statue of a Bearded Man or from Athena.

*Special thanks to #p1prototipos for printing my remix! Great job! Thanks!

description.text:
This is a Barrel extension I designed for my NERF Stryfe, it has a clean outside and a decorative barrel rifling on the inside. Should fit other NERFs that support bayonet barrel extensions.

Designed in OnShape: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/fa3e34bb465a253d7817d529/w/8e7108d1335bbf100e561f57/e/f89d5c7e0345e26ca3927680

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

As there is a support with 0.2 mm air gap for easy break off, I strongly recommend using 0.2mm layer height.

Tip: Use concentric/circular top fill pattern to get a more machined look.

Break off the support

Use a pair of pliers to grip the inner circle in the bottom and break it off, it's about 12mm tall.
It's now ready to use. Note that the barrel is keyed (only fit one way).

comments.text: does it work for rival blasters? I have a barrel mount on my rival Apollo and want a barrel on it, this would work great, but would it restrict the balls at all?

comments.text: I just noticed your picture has the same helical stripe up the exterior sheel that my print did. I had previously considered that an error, but was it intentional or have you been able to explain it?
comments.author: Propter_Hoc

comments.text: It's the seam, where the layers start and end. There are ways to handle it but i don't think you can get rit of them completely. Some slicers have different seam positions you can try. Tweaking extrusion multiplier might help some too.
comments.author: Propter_Hoc

comments.text: Thanks, that gives me something to get started reading about it with. The sander made it disappear quickly enough that I was mostly asking out of curiosity.
comments.author: ornotermes

comments.text: The air gap made the print fail for me for some reason
comments.author: Masky

comments.text: What layer height did you use?
comments.author: Masky

comments.text:
.2 as suggested.
It doesnt make good contact at the air gap, makes a small spaghetti pile and after a while of printing on top of that disconnects completely and the "upper ring" is pushed off. I tried twice but had to stop the print sadly. Might be my cooling or my settings as it seems to work perfectly for other people. I'm currently printing it upside down which I think should work.
comments.author: ornotermes

comments.text: Hmmm, tricky. I haven't seen that issue my self. When printing above the air gap the plastic is gonna droop down, but if the cooling is too aggressive or possibly if the temperature is to low it might not stick. Try less cooling and maybe bump your print temp a few degrees.
comments.author: Masky

comments.text: Are you printing with PLA or some other filament?
comments.author: Masky

comments.text: I'm printing with PLA
comments.author: Propter_Hoc

comments.text: Hrm...that was just a guess.  My next guess would be check your temps and see if maybe you aren't running a little hot.  I would also check to make sure your print program didn't try to "auto repair" the air gap or take similar "corrective action."  On XYZWare, I click "cancel" when I get an error message at startup that says "problems were found for this model, auto repair?"  But, it is also possible that is a preference in your software that has to be toggled.  If neither of those ideas work, maybe double check that you aren't selecting supports, since the supports are already part of this model.
comments.author: Masky

comments.text: This thing is sick!  It printed flawlessly and installed in seconds!  The rifling absolutely makes the project; it is so intimidating I love the way it changed the character of my whole build.  Thank you.

Thanks to Lenbok's design on showing how to use the screw thread library:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793

Simple table that screws onto a Dremel (or other rotary tools). Rebate into your work bench and then you can sand or grind a square edge. Use PPE and common sense when working with rotary tools.

Added the scad file so you can tweak.

Just added a new scad that allows you to make a bevel table. Although 45 deg is a bit extreme and the printed thread is not as good as I would like,but it still worked.

Clean out the burrs well and make sure bit spins freely else the tool can unscrew itself. Also PLA can melt if you get too much heat on and it goes like Jello.

title: Mech City: Construction Mech
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Mech City is a line of cute mecha, accessories, vehicles and playsets that you can 3D print! The Construction Mech set includes the Mech as well as accessories for the Mech to use or share with other sets to combine in different ways. The Mech City Construction Crew is on the job and ready to build all your roads and structures in Mech City.
This set includes the following:

  • Construction Crew (6 Mech City People)
  • arms (right and left)
  • fuel tank back pack
  • torso
  • tread legs
  • cockpit
  • neck
  • head/canopy
  • Construction Gun
  • CraneHalf (print 2)
  • EquipGrip
  • Clobber Fist
  • Spanner

The Clobber Fist can be used like brass knuckles on the Mech, or can be combined with the spanner, 2 crane halves, and Construction Gun for a Wrecking Ball weapon for the Mech. The Wrecking Ball crane can also be used with the Tank Tread vehicle from the Vehicle pack as a Construction Crane.
